title: Mientjes has specialised in the ethnoarcheaology and postmedieval archaeology of rural landscapes and modern peasant histories in southern Italy. After receiving his BA and MA from Leiden University, the Netherlands, he studied for a PhD (1997–2002; University of Wales, Lampeter) into the development of pastoral landscapes in central and western Sardinia during the last 200 years, applying both landscape archaeological and ethnohistorical methods. Since 2002 he has held various postdoctoral positions in the UK and the Netherlands (University of Glasgow, 2002–2004; VU University of Amsterdam, 2005–2010) working on a research project concerning the study of modern rural landscapes and histories on the islands of Sardinia and Sicily within a wider Mediterranean context. His main interests are how up-to-date discussions and strands in the postmedieval and historical archaeology of the Anglo-Saxon world relate to and are applicable to the archaeology of modern times in Italy and southern Europe generally, including topics such as rural capitalism and modernity
